As head of the city's administrative machinery, Ndubiwa had gravitas. Public administration in Zim has gone to the dogs; perhaps it's more accurate to say the dogs have gone to public administration. We robustly reject mediocrity because we know what this country is capable of.

With Ndubiwa at the helm as town clerk, Bulawayo was consistently the cleanest city in Africa; that honour now belongs to Kigali in Rwanda. Those days, public transport was reliable. Potholes were rare.Littering was unheard of.Piped water was safe.We received free milk at school.

Mike Ndubiwa, who has died, had a profound impact on some of us when we were growing up in Bulawayo. I remember him vividly. My late uncle was an administrative officer and I recall Ndubiwa's warm greetings whenever we met in the hallowed corridors of City Hall (under the clock). https://t.co/jzCX63FCAu

...Soul Jah Love and "mafesi" conjured up some lyrical magic, summarising in a few potent words the existential struggles of Zimbabwe's wretched urban youth. That's Soul Musaka's legacy. RIP Mwana waSithembeni.

When a plundered economy was decaying, poverty-stricken families were terrorised by hunger, primitive diseases were killing mercilessly, life became an unbearable nightmare and political dissent was met with unmitigated violence...

To be sure, they did not invent street lingo; they simply infused it with an irresistible dynamism. Geniuses who excel at their craft are often labelled as mad. But Soul Jah Love reminded us that the world is not a rational place; madness is the rule, rather than the exception.

The enchanting artistry of a flawed genius. At his peak, the supremely gifted chanter was without peer. Soul Jah Love was part of an urban revolution which transformed the Shona language into a vivid art form, an organic tapestry, a vehicle for ghetto youth solidarity. https://t.co/SR1e3AWi5q

4/4 Owing to poor planning,we've seen a serious shortage of reagents,substances used in lab analysis. An unfortunate consequences is that HIV viral-load testing has been hard hit,as the reagents are being diverted to Covid-19 testing. There's no substitute for competent planning.

3/4 I find it astonishing that, since March, the govt now says the country only has 84 ventilators for Covid-19. How many ICU nurses do we have? Where are the anaesthetists? Where is the oxygen equipment?

2/4 Anyway, that's besides the point. The govt doesn't have a vaccine plan right now. Zim began Covid-19 testing at the National Microbiology Reference Lab mid-February 2020. The first case was recorded 20 March. Surely,by now there should have been a solid vaccine plan in place.

1/4 The Parliamentary Health Committee has been told that, when a vaccine becomes available, the following groups will be prioritised: Frontline health workers,MPs, security forces and ministers. That's insane! It should be: frontline staff, elderly, those with co-morbidities.

Clearly, the health of citizens isn't a priority. How on earth can a govt allocate US$170m and then expect the donor community to chip in with a whopping US$500m? If a country doesn't prioritise its own healthcare, why should anyone expect "imperialist" donors to pick up the tab?

In 2020, the govt allocated ZW$54.7bn (about US$170m) to health, which was 13% of total national budget, below the 15% threshold stipulated by the Abuja Declaration. As a result, per capita spending on health in Zim is well below US$50, compared to the region's US$90. A pittance.

Crumbling healthcare is the outcome of a multi-faceted governance crisis that pervades every facet of life in this country. The situation is dire:Gross under-funding of hospitals,corruption,decaying health infrastructure,exodus of medical professionals,low investment in research.

The rapidly escalating Covid-19 death toll has rudely reminded Zimbabwe's political elites that they dare not neglect the healthcare sector. The state of the health system is literally a matter of life and death. Destroying the health sector is tantamount to criminal negligence.

Medical personnel at public hospitals are terrified by the heightened risk of contracting Covid. I'm not surprised by the sharply rising number of nurses and doctors who are testing positive.They won a court case reinstating shorter working hours but govt is disregarding the law.

A doctor recounted a scary incident where he attended to a patient who initially returned a false negative, only to test positive a week later. Throughout that time, the doctor had not even worn proper PPE while attending to the patient!

Another health professional said Covid-19 test kits are scarce. When medical personnel request the kits for staff use, they're not readily provided. And yet when a powerful politician demands test kits, they become available. Personal protective equipment is  not always provided.

Today I spoke to several health professionals from various parts of Zim. One doctor said she found it amazing that people were suddenly alarmed by the non-availability of ventilators. "We don't even have something as basic as airtime for contact tracing, let alone ventilators."

This is a very peculiar generation. They would rather mob Ginimbi's funeral procession (may he rest in peace),than take a principled stand on the crucial issues of the day. If young people,who constitute the majority,are not worried about service delivery,what do they care about?

Considering how young the population is, there is a danger that we may end up with a demographic majority who think a crumbling and decaying polity is very normal. In other words, they have never experienced a normal existence. They were born amid chaos, uncertainty & repression.

Zimbabwe is an extremely young country, with 62% of the population below the age of 25 years. In fact,the average age in this country is 18. Very young indeed! But where are these young people? When will they assert their rights? Have they quietly accepted mediocrity and poverty?

Underlying health conditions (co-morbidities) are a big deal when it comes to Covid-19 infection. The 47 Covid-19 patients admitted to Parirenyatwa Hospital in July had these underlying conditions:
Hypertension 49%
Overweight 19%
Kidney disease 17%
Diabetes 15%
Heart disease 11%

59% of the 47 patients had underlying conditions. 89% were admitted within 3 days of a PCR lab test.On average,Covid-19 patients stayed in the hospital for 5 days.The average age was 48 (with patients ranging between the ages of 20 & 82). Men are more vulnerable (68% of patients)

In the month of July, even with Covid-19 cases increasing alarmingly, Parirenyatwa admitted only 47 Covid-19 patients. Clearly, the hospital's capacity must be scrutinised in the national interest. Where are Zimbabweans getting medical services? Of these patients, 16 died (34%).

Parirenyatwa is the largest hospital in Zimbabwe. In the middle of a Covid-19 crisis and with a clueless govt that has been criminally negligent in running the national health system, it is in the public interest for me as a journalist to use my magnifying glass. Coming up...

At Zesa Enterprises,a subsidiary of Zesa Holdings,goods & services totalling US$253,6m were acquired from suppliers without obtaining 3 quotations. 6 of these transactions (US$23,8m) were processed on quotes obtained via phone. 26 of them totalling US$229,8m didn't have 3 quotes.
